Fig. 1 Schematic illustration for the synthesis route of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst. Fig 2 Fig. 3 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm and pore size distribution of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts with different DA dosages. Fig 3 * The pore size distribution of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst calculated by density function theory (DFT). Fig. 4 Catalytic performance evaluation of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts with different DA mass for DSHP at atmospheric pressure. Fig 4 * Reaction conditions: catalyst 10 mg, 160 ml MeOH, 1.8 ml 98 wt% H2SO4, total flow rate 16.25 ml/min, H2:O2:N2=2.25:4:10, 120 rpm/min, 0 °C, atmospheric pressure, 1.0 h. Fig. 5 Catalytic performance evaluation of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst for the direct synthesis of H2O2 from H2 and O2 at atmospheric pressure. Fig 5 * Reaction conditions: catalyst 10 mg, 160 ml MeOH, 1.8 ml 98 wt% H2SO4, total flow rate 16.25 ml/min, H2:O2:N2=2.25:4:10, 120 rpm/min, 0 °C, atmospheric pressure, 3.0 h. Fig. 6 H2O2 hydrogenation and decomposition evaluation of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst. Fig 6 * Reaction conditions: catalyst 10 mg, 160 ml MeOH, 1.8 ml 98 wt% H2SO4, H2O2 initial concentration 1wt%, total flow rate 12.25 ml/min, H2:O2:N2=2.25:0:10 for H2O2 hydrogenation or total flow rate 10 ml/min, H2:O2:N2=0:0:10 for H2O2 decomposition, 120 rpm/min, 0 °C, atmospheric pressure, 3.0 h. Fig. 7 (a)Total mean square displacement diagram of H2, O2, and CH3OH in the PD-15 model; (b) Total mean square displacement diagram of H2O2 and CH3OH in the PD-15 model * The model consists of three parts: the outer region (dense phase region), the pore region and the inner region (dilute phase region). * The mean square displacement in the model is called the total mean square displacement, and the mean square displacement in the pore is called the mean square displacement, the same below. * The diffusion coefficient in the model is called the total diffusion coefficient, and the diffusion coefficient in the pore is called the diffusion coefficient, the same below. College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Guizhou University Guiyang Guizhou 550025 China A well-defined structural morphology can significantly construct a special catalytic micro-reaction environment to enhance the catalytic performance of Pd catalyst in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen (DSHP). In this study, SiO2 was used as a rigid template, PdCl2 as the Pd precursor, and dopamine hydrochloride (DA) as the carbon and nitrogen source to synthesize a nest-shaped hollow-encapsulated Pd catalyst named PdMulti@ONHCS. This catalyst was successfully constructed via high-temperature pyrolysis of poly dimethyl diallyl ammonium chloride (PDDA), which generated a blasting effect crucial for this formation. Characterization analysis, catalytic performance evaluation experiment, and molecular dynamics simulation were conducted to explore the structure-performance relationship of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst in DSHP. Both experimental and simulation results consistently showed that the nest-shaped hollow structure of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst created a distinctive catalytic microreactor environment with a spatial mass transfer constraint, which was not only conducive to adsorption and enrichment of H2 and O2 at Pd active sites to produce H2O2. In addition, the generated H2O2 can be desorbed from Pd active sites in time and rapidly diffused into the reaction solution, effectively inhibiting the dissociation of species containing OO bonds on the Pd surface, resulting in severe hydrogenation and decomposition side reactions, and improving H2O2 productivity and selectivity. Graphical abstract By organically combining carbon support with structural morphology, a nest-shaped hollow-encapsulated Pd catalyst named PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst was successfully constructed and first used for DSHP from H2 and O2 at atmospheric pressure. PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst with a new structural morphology provided a distinctive catalytic microreactor cavity and constraint effect of spatial mass transfer to enhance the catalytic performance for DSHP, ultimately improving H2O2 productivity and H2O2 selectivity. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pd catalyst Embedded with Pd nanoparticles Nest-shape hollow structure Direct synthesis Hydrogen peroxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a significant inorganic chemical [1]. Pure H2O2 is a light blue and viscous liquid, readily insoluble in water, alcohol, and ether but in benzene and petroleum ether. Pure H2O2 can also readily form a homogeneous mixture with water, colloquially called hydrogen peroxide, as a colorless and transparent liquid [2,3]. Amid the array of chemical oxidants offered by chemists, H2O2 is regarded as one of the most efficient and safest oxidants, boasting a remarkably high active oxygen content of approximately 47.1 %, surpassed only by oxygen molecular. Simultaneously, H2O2 is also considered one of the "greenest oxidant" due to the exclusive generation of water as its oxidation by-product [3–5]. This characteristic precludes the introduction of toxic by-products or substances resistant to separation and degradation, meeting the requirements of green environmental protection and sustainable development. Consequently, it finds widespread applications in diverse fields such as textiles, paper manufacturing, food production, medicine, electronics, aerospace, and eco-friendly chemical synthesis [6–14]. Anthraquinone autoxidation (AO process) currently represents the predominant industrial method for synthesizing H2O2. Not only does this method continuously yield concentrations of 30 % or higher, but it also mitigates the bursting limits associated with H2/O2 gas mixture. However, challenges persist in a complex process flow, high energy consumption, significant environmental pollution, and inherent safety risks in storing and transporting concentrated H2O2 [4,11,15–17]. In contrast, the direct synthesis of H2O2 from H2 and O2 (DSHP) presents distinct advantages, including a simplified process, environmental friendliness, and high atom economy [10,11,17,18]. More importantly, DSHP enables online H2O2 production, facilitating in situ coupling with reactions such as methane oxidation to methanol, cyclohexanone ammoxidation to cyclohexanone oxime, enzymatic oxidation of cyclohexane to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone, among others [19–23]. Consequently, DSHP is regarded as an efficient and environmentally friendly strategy serving as a viable and clean alternative to the AO process [24]. As a noble metal, Pd catalyst exhibits excellent hydrogenation activity and demonstrates superior catalytic performance compared to others in DSHP, such as Pt, Au, and Ag [25–27]. However, both the reaction mechanism and reaction pathway indicate that side reactions caused by OO bond cleavage—namely, H2 and O2 directly generating H2O, H2O2 hydrogenation into H2O and H2O2 decomposition into H2O, are thermodynamically more favorable than the main reaction that H2O2 directly synthesized from H2 and O2 [25,28,29]. This thermodynamic imbalance detrimentally impacts both H2O2 productivity and H2O2 selectivity. Therefore, the suitable design and preparation of Pd catalyst with high activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation process for H2O2 production have become essential questions to improve the catalytic performance of DSHP and have attracted more attention from the research community. A substantial amount of literature on various aspects related to DSHP has emerged. These studies encompass investigations into the catalytic reaction mechanism of Pd catalyst, the modulation of the electronic and geometric structure of active component, the selection and regulation of catalyst support, and the optimization of reaction conditions [3,30–45]. The overarching objective of these investigations is to attenuate the proclivity of Pd catalysts for excessive molecular O2 activation, leading to direct OO bond cleavage and subsequent H2O formation. Additionally, efforts are directed towards inhibiting the dissociation and cleavage of OO bond species on Pd active surface, otherwise leading to undesired hydrogenation and decomposition side reactions. The overarching goal is to achieve Pd catalyst with heightened catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability in this context. The research progress in the selection and regulation of Pd catalyst support mainly focuses on the impact of support type (oxide support, carbon support, heteropoly acid, composite support, MOF and other supports) and property (functional groups, acidity, hydrophilicity and other properties) on the catalytic performance of DSHP [3,30–46]. However, the relationship between support regulation and structure morphology of Pd catalyst, as well as how structure morphology of Pd catalyst affects the catalytic performance of DSHP, has not received sufficient attention and in-depth investigation. The structure morphology of Pd catalyst not only affects the number and distribution of Pd active sites but also, more importantly, influences the mass transfer and diffusion of reactants and products during DSHP process, as well as the reaction kinetic pathway, thereby impacting the catalytic performance of Pd catalyst. A comprehensive investigation into the structure-performance relationship of Pd catalyst in DSHP provides a theoretical strategy for the efficient design of Pd catalyst. Traditional Pd catalyst primarily rely on supported Pd catalyst. However, those issues such as severe agglomeration, detachment, and leaching of Pd nanoparticles are unavoidable [19]. To enhance the thermal stability of Pd nanoparticles during catalyst synthesis and catalytic reaction, Lee research group [37,39,40]. successfully encapsulated Pd nanoparticles in SiO2 using Stöber method which resulted in a series of tightly encapsulated core-shell Pd catalysts, such as Pd@SiO2, Pd@SiO2-PVP2, and Pd@SiO2-Al2O3. Those catalysts not only exhibited excellent H2O2 catalytic activity but also effectively prevented the migration, agglomeration, and detachment of Pd nanoparticles. However, the direct encapsulation of the porous shell around the Pd nanoparticles meant that only the Pd surface in contact with the shell pores could provide Pd active sites for DHSP, significantly reducing the effective utilization of Pd active component. Additionally, the mass transfer and diffusion of reactant and product molecules within the porous shell were confined to the same pore, severely affecting mass transfer and diffusion rate of the catalyst. Then, in order to overcome this problem, Lee research group [41] successfully synthesized the hollow core-shell Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst by Stöber method and KOH etching. The result showed that, compared with Pd@SiO2 catalyst, Pd@void@ZrO2 exposed more Pd active surface area (23.7 and 36.8 m2/g-Pd, respectively). Furthermore, the hollow space in the Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst allowed more reactant molecules to access the Pd active surface, thereby directly facilitating the synthesis of H2O2. Lin research group [42] also successfully synthesized the hollow core-shell Pd@HCS catalyst with Pd nanoparticles as the core and porous carbon as the shell by self-assembly method. The abundant microporous structure of the carbon shell not only enhanced the mass transfer rate of reactant and product molecules but also effectively prevented the migration, agglomeration, and detachment of Pd nanoparticles during catalyst synthesis and activity evaluation process. The ingenious design of the hollow core-shell Pd catalyst solved both the limited mass transfer rate and the insufficient exposed surface area of Pd active component inherent in tightly encapsulated core-shell Pd catalyst. To further enhance the utilization of Pd active component, Lin research group [44,45] successfully synthesized hollow-encapsulated PdMulti@HCS catalyst using a hard template sacrifice method. In this design, Pd nanoparticles were dispersed and embedded within the inner wall of the hollow porous carbon shell. The carbon shell not only effectively prevented the migration, agglomeration, and detachment of Pd nanoparticles but also ensured the maximal exposure to the reaction system, providing ample Pd active sites. At the same time, the abundant microporous structure of the porous carbon shell can ensure the optimal mass transfer and diffusion capability to improve the catalytic activity of DSHP. However, it is noteworthy that compared with the open catalytic reaction environment of traditional supported Pd catalyst, both hollow core-shell Pd catalyst and hollow-encapsulated Pd catalyst were nano-reactors with hollow cavity structure and internal encapsulation of Pd active particles. The hollow cavity formed a limited space and provided a special catalytic microreaction environment, which were conducive to the enrichment of reactant H2 and O2 molecules around the Pd nanoparticles located in the inner wall, speeding up the catalytic reaction rate. Nevertheless, constructing a hollow porous shell implies that Pd nanoparticles are not directly exposed to the reaction solution. Reactant H2 and O2 molecules must undergo adsorption and mass transfer and diffusion through the porous shell before reaching Pd active surface, introducing a constraint effect of spatial mass transfer. If the constraint effect of spatial mass transfer in the porous shell is strong, resulting in significant mass transfer resistance, the rate of H2O2 generation may be slowed. Additionally, generated H2O2 may not promptly detach from Pd active sites due to the substantial mass transfer resistance in the porous shell, leading to delayed diffusion from the hollow cavity through the shell to the reaction solution. That can result in an excessively high concentration of H2O2 within the catalyst cavity, exacerbating the degree of hydrogenation and decomposition side reactions and causing a rapid decline in catalytic activity. Addressing how to mitigate the constraint effect of spatial mass transfer to the porous shell, that is reducing mass transfer and diffusion resistance, is of paramount significance in enhancing the catalytic capability of hollow core-shell Pd catalyst and hollow-encapsulated Pd catalyst for DSHP. Carbon support has attracted close attention due to their high surface area, abundant pore structures, and ease of heteroatom doping and chemical modification, making it considered effective support for Pd catalyst. Specifically, rational design and controlled construction can lead to the formation of special hollow structure in carbon support, rather than solely serving as carbon support. Additionally, there is a synergistic effect between Pd nanoparticles and the hollow carbon shell, leading to properties different from those of a single carbon support. Therefore, by organically combining the carbon support and catalyst morphology, an appropriately designed hollow porous carbon shell with an open structure has been successfully constructed, resulting in a nest-shaped hollow-encapsulated Pd catalyst. This Pd catalyst with a new structural morphology was recorded as PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst. Then, the research work primarily investigated the structure-performance relationship of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst in terms of structure morphology and catalytic performance for DSHP mainly through experimental research and molecular dynamics simulation method. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Palladium chloride (PdCl2, 59–60 wt% of Pd), Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98 %), Poly dimethyl diallyl ammonium chloride (PDDA, 20 % in water), and Dopamine hydrochloride (DA, 98 %) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.; Sodium borohydride (NaBH4, 98 %), Ammonium hydroxide (NH3·H2O, 25–28 %), and Hydrofluoric acid (HF, 40 %) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.; Ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.7 wt%) and Methanol (CH3OH, 99.5 wt%) were purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. All experimental reagents were analytical grade and used without any further purification. Deionized water was used throughout the experiment. 2.2 Typical synthesis of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst The synthesis route of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst is shown in Fig. 1 , which mainly include sol-gel, functional modification, in-situ reduction, carbonization, and selective etching processes. Firstly, rigid template SiO2 nanosphere was synthesized by Stöber method and functionalized with the water-soluble cationic polymer PDDA to achieve a higher positive charge density called SiO2-PDDA nanocomposite. Pd precursor PdCl4 2- was adsorbed on the surface of SiO2-PDDA through the interaction of positive and negative charges, and PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA nanocomposite were obtained through in-situ reduction with fresh NaBH4 solution. Then, using PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA nanocomposite as the core and DA as the carbon and nitrogen source, PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA@PDA nanocomposite was formed through self-assembly reaction. Subsequently, high-temperature carbonization and in-situ nitrogen doping were carried out for PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA@PDA nanocomposite under an inert atmosphere, followed by selective etching of SiO2 rigid template using hydrofluoric acid. The obtained material was then oxidized in air at 250 °C and reduced in a hydrogen atmosphere, yielding a nest-shape N-doped hollow carbon sphere embedded with Pd nanoparticles called PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst. The typical synthesis steps are illustrated as follows. 2.2.1 SiO2 nanospheres prepared by Stöber method SiO2 nanospheres used as the rigid template were synthesized using Stöber method. 4.5 ml TEOS was quickly added into the mixture solution included 62 ml ethanol, 25 ml deionized water, and 1.5 ml ammonium hydroxide, and then stirred at 25 °C for 2 h. The final product was centrifuged 1 time with ethanol, and centrifuged 3 times with deionized water, and then denoted as SiO2. 2.2.2 SiO2 nanospheres modified by PDDA The above prepared SiO2 nanospheres were ultrasonically dispersed in 100 ml deionized water, then 1.5 ml PDDA was added dropwise into this uniform mixture, and then stirred at 35 °C for 16 h. The final product was centrifuged 3 times with deionized water and then denoted as SiO2-PDDA. 2.2.3 Preparation of PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA The above prepared SiO2-PDDA nanocomposites were ultrasonically dispersed in 100 ml deionized water. Then, 1 ml H2PdCl4 solution (0.075 M) was slowly added dropwise into this uniform mixture, and then stirred at 35 °C for 20 h. After the completion of the stirring reaction, 500 μl fresh NaBH4 solution (5 wt%) was slowly added dropwise, and then continued to react at 35 °C for 3 h. The final product was centrifuged 3 times with deionized water and then denoted as PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA. 2.2.4 Preparation of PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA@PDA and PdMulti@ONHCS Firstly, the above prepared PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA nanocomposites were ultrasonically dispersed in a mixture solution included 70 ml deionized water and 30 ml ethanol. Then, 2 ml ammonium hydroxide was added, and then stirred at 30 °C for 30 min. Next, 0.35 g DA was added into this uniform mixture, and the self-assembly polymerization reaction was carried out at 30 °C for 16 h. The product, after reaction, was centrifuged 3 times with deionized water, and then dried in an oven overnight at 80 °C. The obtained dried product, which was named PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA@PDA nanocomposites, was carbonized in N2 atmosphere at 600 °C (The programmed heating rate was 5 °C/min, maintained at 250 °C for 1 h and 600 °C for 2 h). Then, the high-temperature carbonized product was dispersed in a mixture solution included 35 ml deionized water and 5 ml hydrofluoric acid and then etched at room temperature for 24 h to remove the SiO2 rigid template. The obtained product was centrifuged 3 times with deionized water, and then dried in an oven overnight at 80 °C. Lastly, the intermediate product was oxidized in an air atmosphere at 250 °C for 2 h and reduced in a hydrogen atmosphere at 250 °C for 2.5 h. The finally obtained product was denoted as PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst. A series of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts preparing with different mass of DA followed the typical synthesis method mentioned above, with DA mass of 0.2 g, 0.3 g, 0.35 g, 0.4 g, and 0.5 g, respectively. 2.3 The characterization of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Nova Nano 450, FEI, USA) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F20, FEI, USA) were used to detect the microscopic morphology, structure and nanoparticle size of the samples. The phases of the samples were detected using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D8 Advance, Bruker, Germany). The elemental composition and chemical state on the surface of the samples were determined using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, K-Alpha Plus, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The graphitization and defect degree of the samples were detected using a laser microscope confocal Raman spectrometer (LadRAM HR Evoluion, HORIBA, France). The elemental composition of N, C, and H of the samples was detected using an elemental analyzer (Elemental Analyser, Euro EA3000, EuroVector, Italy). The specific surface area and pore structure of the samples were determined using an N2 adsorption/desorption physical adsorption instrument (ASAP2460, Micrometrics, USA). The loading of Pd in the catalysts were determined using an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Aglient 5110, Aglient, USA). Detailed test methods were provided in supplementary material. 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst The catalytic performance evaluation experiment of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst for DSHP was conducted in a jacketed glass reactor (Fig. S1). The reaction temperature was maintained at 0 °C, and the reaction pressure was at atmospheric pressure. N2 (99.999 %) was used as the carrier gas, while H2 (99.999 %) and O2 (99.999 %) were used as the reaction gasses. The total gas flow rate was 16.25 ml/min, with H2 at 2.25 ml/min, O2 at 4 ml/min, and N2 at 10 ml/min (It is important to note that this gas mixture is within the explosive range of hydrogen). The flow rate of H2, O2, and N2 were controlled using mass flow controllers (MFCs). A mixture solution of 160 ml methanol (CH3OH, 99.7 wt%) and 1.8 ml concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 98 wt%) was used as the reaction medium, and the evaluation amount of the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst was approximately 10 mg. To prevent explosion risk due to the reaction mixture being within the hydrogen explosive limit, the catalyst was first dispersed in 20 ml methanol solution before being transferred to the reactor, with a total methanol volume of 160 ml. The concentration of generated H2O2 was determined by the iodine titration method and the content of H2 and O2 in the exhaust gas after the reaction was determined using GC-9860 gas chromatography. The H2 conversion, H2O2 selectivity, and H2O2 productivity were calculated by using the following equations, respectively: H 2 conversion ( % ) = moles of H 2 reacted moles of H 2 feed × 100 % H 2 O 2 s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = m o l e s o f H 2 O 2 f o r m e d m o l e s o f H 2 r e a c t e d × 100 % H 2 O 2 p r o d u c t i v i t y ( m m o l − H 2 O 2 / g P d · h − 1 ) = m m o l e s o f H 2 O 2 f o r m e d weight of Pd ( g ) in catalyst × reaction time ( h ) The hydrogenation and decomposition evaluation experiments of the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst were also evaluated in the above-mentioned jacketed glass reactor by the same reaction conditions, except that a methanol solution containing 1 wt% H2O2 was introduced. Only H2 and N2 were introduced into the reactor for the hydrogenation evaluation experiment. The flow rates of H2 and N2 were 2.25 ml/min and 10 ml/min, respectively, while all other experimental conditions remained unchanged. The amount of H2O2 hydrogenated during the reaction was determined by measuring the change in H2O2 concentration before and after the reaction. For the decomposition evaluation experiment, only N2 was introduced into the reactor, with a flow rate of 10 ml/min, while all other experimental condition was similar to the hydrogenation evaluation experiment. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure morphology characterization of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst Fig. 2 (a-l) shows the TEM and SEM characterization results of the typical synthesis process of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst (PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst prepared with 0.35 g DA was used for characterization analysis). As shown in Fig. 2 (a, b, c, d, e, j, k), the SiO2 nanospheres prepared by Stöber method exhibit regular morphology and uniform size. With an average diameter of 145.1 nm, this is consistent with the average size of hollow cavity in PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst, indicating that SiO2 forms rigid structural nanospheres, and its size will not be changed by high-temperature heat treatment, thereby determining the hollow cavity diameter of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst. PDDA is a water-soluble and strong cationic polyelectrolyte with a high positive charge density, exhibiting a strong affinity towards anionic substances [47,48]. To investigate the surface modification effect of PDDA on SiO2, XPS full spectrum, high-resolution element spectrum, and XPS spectrum quantitative analysis are conducted on SiO2 and SiO2-PDDA, as shown in Figs. S2, S3, and Table S1. The characterization results indicate that, in addition to the characteristic elements Si and O, SiO2 also contains C element, with a Si/O ratio of approximately 2.1, which is consistent with the stoichiometric composition of SiO2. The C element in SiO2 may be caused by incomplete hydrolysis of a minimal amount of TEOS, resulting in the residue of carbon-containing groups or maybe by carbon pollution during the sample testing process. Surface modification of SiO2 with PDDA increases the content of C and N elements. PDDA mainly contains CC bonds and CH bonds but lacks oxygen-containing bonds. After modifying PDDA on the SiO2 surface, the quantity of CC bonds and CH bonds will increase, thus increasing the content of C element and decreasing the content of O element in SiO2-PDDA. A comparative analysis of the XPS full spectra of SiO2 and SiO2-PDDA reveals a significantly stronger C1s peak in SiO2-PDDA than in SiO2. At the same time, a characteristic peak appears in the XPS full spectrum of SiO2-PDDA at about 402 eV, corresponding to the binding energy of N1s. Further analysis of the high-resolution N1s spectrum of SiO2-PDDA shows that the main peak, located at a binding energy of 401.72 eV, is attributed to graphitic nitrogen, while the shoulder peak at a binding energy of 398.15 eV is attributed to pyridinic nitrogen [49]. The XPS characterization results show that PDDA is successfully modified on the surface of SiO2 spheres and can not change the chemical structure. Simultaneously, the surface functionalization with PDDA imparts a higher positive charge density to the SiO2 surface. The palladium precursor PdCl4 2- is adsorbed onto the SiO2-PDDA surface through electrostatic attraction between positive and negative charges. Subsequently, the Pd nanoparticles are formed and dispersed, loading on the surface of SiO2-PDDA by in-situ reduction with fresh NaBH4 solution and forming PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA nanocomposite spheres. DA can undergo oxidation and self-polymerization to generate polydopamine (PDA) under alkaline alcohol-water condition. The main advantage of PDA is that it can be easily adsorbed on various material surfaces, including superhydrophobic surface, with controllable shell thickness and good adsorption stability [50]. Therefore, using PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA as the core, a gradual coverage of the PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA surface with a stable and closely adhering PDA shell is achieved through DA oxidation-self-polymerization process in alkaline alcohol-water solution. The comparison of the enlarged images in Fig. 2 (c-d) also shows that the surface of the PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA becomes rougher after encapsulation with the PDA shell. As PDDA is a high polymer, it rapidly decomposes and is accompanied by strong gas release behavior at a carbonization temperature of 250 °C [47,48], generating pressure that can disrupt the shell to form an opening. That is, the blasting effect occurs during the high-temperature pyrolysis of PDDA. Fig. 2(e) indicates that the explosive effect generated during the high-temperature carbonization process using PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA core-shell nanocomposites, along with the controlled thickness of the PDA shell, can cause partial collapse and shrinkage of the PDA shell to form an open structure (yellow dashed lines). Concurrently, the PDA shell also contracted and encapsulated the PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA during high-temperature carbonization. After removing the SiO2 rigid template through hydrofluoric acid etching, Pd nanoparticles were partially embedded within the carbon shell, resulting in a nest-like N-doped hollow carbon sphere. The carbon shell contracted to approximately 6.0 nm after high-temperature carbonization, maintaining good uniformity and spherical morphology. SEM and magnified images of PdMulti@ONHCS (Fig. 2(g)) clearly reveal typical opening defect on the surface of the carbon shell, consistent with Fig. 2(e). Analysis of the TEM (Fig. 2(e)) and SEM (Fig. 2(g)) images of PdMulti@ONHCS confirmed that the prepared PdMulti@ONHCS exhibited a nest-like hollow structure. As can be seen from Fig. S8 (c), the opening pore size of the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst is about 39.4 nm. In Fig. 2(f), the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy image of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst clearly shows that Pd nanoparticles exhibit a well-ordered crystalline structure with a surface crystal plane spacing of 0.228 nm, which is consistent with the face-centered cubic crystal structure spacing of Pd (111) crystal plane [44]. Additionally, the XRD spectrum of the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst, as shown in Fig. S7, exhibits a broad diffraction peak at 2θ value about of 23°, corresponding to the amorphous carbon diffraction peak associated with the catalyst's carbon shell [51]. Moreover, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Pd (111), Pd (200), Pd (220), Pd (311) and Pd (222) crystal planes at 2θ values about 40.0°, 46.5°, 67.8°, 81.7°, and 86.2°, respectively, which are in good agreement with the standard diffraction spectrum of Pd (JCPDS#87–0643) [42,52,53]. Among them, the intensity of the characteristic diffraction peak of the Pd (111) crystal plane is the strongest, indicating that Pd nanoparticles on the catalyst exist in a face-centered cubic structure, consistent with the TEM characterization results (Fig. 2(f)). Tian et al. [54]. and Lee et al. [55]. based on DFT calculation and experimental research results suggested that the Pd (111) crystal facet was more favorable for DSHP. Conversely, Wang et al. [1], based on microkinetic reaction dynamics, found that the Pd (100) crystal facet was more advantageous for DSHP. Despite differing views on the optimal crystal facet for H2O2 synthesis, many researchers believed that the Pd (111) facet was the primary active surface for DSHP [56–60], attributed to the compact atomic arrangement on the surface that inhibited excessive activation of O2, thereby enhancing H2O2 selectivity [54]. From Fig. 2 (h-i), it can be observed that the particle size of Pd nanoparticles on both PdMulti/SiO2-PDDA and PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst are basically the same. That indicates that the loading method, where Pd nanoparticles are partially embedded in the inner surface of the carbon shell, could effectively prevent the migration and aggregation of Pd nanoparticles during high-temperature heat treatment, enhancing their stability against separation and sintering. Pd nanoparticles can also avoid falling off due to strong mechanical agitation under harsh reaction conditions, further improving the catalyst's stability. Additionally, the statistical analysis reveals that the particle size of Pd nanoparticles is mainly concentrated in the range of 5.5–7.5 nm, with an average size of 6.5 nm. The narrow particle size distribution and smaller particle size expose more Pd active sites, contributing favorably to the catalytic performance of DSHP at atmospheric pressure [61]. In particular, the XPS spectrum quantification results of Pd3d for the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst are shown in Table S2. Pd3d exhibits two pairs of characteristic peaks with binding energy located at 335.76 eV and 341.02 eV, attributed to Pd03d5/2 and Pd03d3/2, and peaks at 337.78 eV and 343.04 eV, assigned to Pd2+3d5/2 and Pd2+3d3/2 [62], respectively. It indicated that the Pd nanoparticles in the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst existed in both Pd0 and Pd2+ chemical states, with a Pd0/Pd2+ ratio of 55.98/44.02 (1.27). The chemical state of Pd active component affects catalytic behavior, and the presence of a certain proportion of Pd0/Pd2+ composition can not only promote H2 dissociation activation to improve the H2 conversion rate but also provide active sites for non-dissociative activation of O2 molecules, avoiding excessive activation of O2 molecules leading to OO bond cleavage and dissociation of species containing OO bonds, thereby enhancing H2O2 productivity and H2O2 selectivity [63,64]. Elemental analysis characterizes the nitrogen content in t hollow carbon shell of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst as 6.16 %. Simultaneously, based on N1s high-resolution spectrum and XPS spectrum quantification analysis (Fig. S6 (d) and Table S3), peaks at binding energy of 398.65 eV, 400.10 eV, and 400.96 eV are attributed to pyridinic nitrogen, pyrrolic nitrogen, and graphitic nitrogen, respectively, with graphitic nitrogen being the dominant form [65,66]. Nitrogen doping, primarily in the form of graphitic nitrogen, can effectively regulate the electron structure of the carbon support, leading to local charge accumulation on the carbon surface. Serving as coordinating sites, it is beneficial for stabilizing small Pd nanoparticles, regulating the electron effects of Pd nanoparticles, and improving the coverage of O2 on the Pd surface and H2O2 generation rate [52,67]. Adjusting the mass of DA allowed for the preparation of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts with different pore sizes and shell wall thicknesses. As shown in Fig. S8 (a-j) and Fig. S9 (a-e), when the DA mass is 0.2 g, the carbon shell formed by PDA is relatively thin (5.4 nm) with poor thermal stability, leading to larger opening (55.2 nm) and extensive fragmentation of the carbon shell, resulting in a bowl-shaped nest-like hollow carbon sphere with numerous damaged carbon shell fragments. As the DA mass increases, the thickness of the carbon shell formed by PDA also increases (6.0 nm), leading to smaller openings in the nest-like structure due to the reduced explosive effect, and the structure of the hollow carbon spheres becomes more stable, yielding a large number of structurally intact nest-like hollow carbon spheres. When the DA mass reaches 0.5 g, the thickness of the carbon shell increases to 8.1 nm. The thicker carbon shell not only reduces the diameter of the nest-like openings formed by the explosive effect to 33.4 nm but also results in a few hollow carbon spheres with no surface opening (Fig. 7i). This indicates that by adjusting the DA mass could control the thickness of the carbon shell and, in conjunction with PDDA, the explosive effect during high-temperature treatment can regulate the aperture size of the hollow carbon spheres, leading to a well-structured, appropriately thick, and properly opened nest-like PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst. Notably, as the DA mass increases from 0.2 g to 0.35 g, the particle size of Pd nanoparticles in the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst decreases from 9.0 nm to 6.5 nm, which may be related to the integrity of the catalyst's shell structure. When DA is added at 0.2 g, the prepared PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst not only has a thinner shell but also contained numerous fragments from the explosive effect. The loss of the protective shell allowed Pd nanoparticles embedded in these fragments to agglomerate during high-temperature treatment, resulting in larger Pd nanoparticles. However, with an increase in DA to 0.35 g, the prepared PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst exhibited a more intact shell structure, effectively suppressing the agglomeration of Pd nanoparticles during high-temperature treatment and leading to smaller Pd nanoparticles. Further increasing the DA amount does not significantly alter the Pd nanoparticle size (Fig. S9), supporting our hypothesis that the integrity of the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst's shell structure was a crucial factor affecting the Pd nanoparticle size. The XRD spectra of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts prepared with different dosages of DA are presented in Fig. S10. As depicted in Fig. S10, characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to Pd (111), Pd (200), Pd (220), Pd (311) and Pd (222) crystal planes appear at 2θ values about 40.1°, 46.7°, 68.1°, 82.1°, and 86.3°, respectively, across all PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts prepared with a different dosage of DA. The characteristic peak corresponding to the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst prepared with a selected DA dosage of 0.35 g is chosen for the Pd (111) crystal plane. Utilizing the Scherrer equation, the calculated average diameter of Pd nanoparticles is determined to be 6.8 nm. consistent with the results obtained from TEM analysis. The Raman spectra of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts prepared with different dosages of DA are presented in Fig. S11. As can be seen from Fig. S11, PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts prepared with different dosages of DA all exhibit two prominent characteristic peaks near 1343 cm-1 and 1589 cm-1, corresponding to the d-band (representing lattice defect in disordered carbon structure) and the G-band (indicating stretching vibration of ordered carbon structure with sp2 hybridization), respectively. The peak area or intensity ratio between the d-band and G-band (ID/IG) reflects the degree of graphitization and defect density in carbon materials. A higher ID/IG value indicates a lower degree of graphitization and a higher defect density in carbon materials [51]. Moreover, increasing the dosage of DA decreases the ID/IG intensity ratio from 0.99 to 0.89. This reduction suggests that, under the same carbonization conditions, the increased dosage of DA enhances the graphitization degree of the hollow carbon shell, facilitating electron conduction to regulate the electronic effects of Pd nanoparticles [52,67]. Furthermore, this observation is in concordance with the XPS characterization results. Table 1 and Fig. 3 present the pore structure parameters, N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, and pore size distribution of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts prepared with different dosages of DA, respectively. As seen from Table 1, all the BET specific surface area of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts are relatively large, but the pore volume increase with the increase in dosages of DA. Simultaneously, Fig. 3 also shows that all the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts belongs to the typical Type IV isotherm according to the IUPAC classification [51]. At lower relative pressure, the N2 adsorption capacity increases sharply with the increase of relative pressure, followed by a gradual adsorption plateau. This phenomenon arises from the saturation of N2 monolayer adsorption on micropores, leading to multilayer adsorption, indicating that the presence of abundant micropores in PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst. However, at higher relative pressure, the N2 adsorption isotherms exhibit a steep rise, indicating capillary condensation. Moreover, the desorption line displays a pronounced hysteresis loop, signifying the presence of mesoporous structure in the catalyst. The DFT pore size distribution further demonstrates the existence of numerous pores distributed in the range of 0.5–1.5 nm for micropores and 50–100 nm for mesopores and macropores. Based on previous research by our research group [42,44], micropores with a size distribution of 0.5–1.5 nm are attributed to the pore structure of the carbon shell. During the high-temperature carbonization process, the collaborative action of PDDA and PDA carbon precursor led to the generation of numerous small gas molecules such as CO2, CO, and H2O, facilitating the etching of the carbon shell and forming abundant microporous pores under high-temperature condition. Mesopores and macropores in the range of 50–100 nm correspond to the internal cavity of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst, determined by the diameter of SiO2 spheres. While N2 adsorption/desorption characterizes the largest pore size as 100 nm, the distribution of numerous large mesopores and macropores, as indicated by the catalyst's cavity size distribution, and confirms the presence of internal cavities in PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst. At the same time, the previous research work of our research group [42,44] also showed that the high specific surface area and rich microporous structure of hollow carbon shell are very conducive to the adsorption and enrichment of H2 and O2 molecules in the reaction solution, so as to improve their coverage and interaction on Pd active surface and promote the generation of H2O2. 3.2 The structure-performance relationship of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst for DSHP The catalytic performance of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts prepared with different mass of DA for DSHP at atmospheric pressure is shown in Fig. 4 . The results indicate that both the H2O2 productivity and H2 conversion initially increase and then decrease with increasing DA mass, exhibiting a volcano-type trend, while the H2O2 selectivity increases with the DA mass. As shown in Fig. S9, when the DA amount is low, the PDA layer formed by oxidative self-polymerization is thin. During high-temperature carbonization, the strong explosive effect can easily cause the carbon shell formed from PDA to break, making it difficult to achieve a complete hollow structure. SEM characterization results of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst (Fig. S8) confirm this observation. Without the protective carbon shell, exposed Pd nanoparticles are prone to migration and aggregation into larger particles during high-temperature treatment (Fig. S9 (c)). Previous literature has demonstrated that the particle size of Pd nanoparticles significantly affects the catalytic activity for direct H2O2 synthesis. Larger Pd nanoparticles with higher crystallinity provide fewer Pd active sites, especially those with low-energy sites such as edges and corners, which adversely affects H2 conversion and H2O2 productivity [61]. Increasing the DA mass leads to a thicker PDA layer formed by oxidative self-polymerization (Fig. S9), which helps build a better-structured, appropriately thick nest-like hollow carbon sphere. Such a well-structured nest-like hollow carbon sphere enhances the sintering resistance of the embedded Pd nanoparticles, facilitating the formation of smaller Pd nanoparticles. Additionally, an optimal shell thickness helps maximize the exposure of Pd nanoparticles, which is beneficial for improving both H2 conversion and H2O2 productivity. The nest-like openings of the hollow carbon shell, combined with the abundant microporous structure, enhance the circulation and diffusion of reactant and product molecules within the hollow micro-reactor, promoting H2O2 formation while preventing H2O2 accumulation and thus suppressing side reactions such as H2O2 hydrogenation and decomposition, which enhances H2O2 selectivity. As the DA amount continues to increase, the PDA layer also becomes thicker, resulting in a decrease in the aperture size of the nest-like openings due to the explosive effect (Fig. S8). Thicker carbon shells and more enclosed hollow cavities (Fig. S9) lead to increased spatial mass transfer constraints, raising the resistance to mass transfer and diffusion of H2 and O2 into the hollow micro-reactor. Additionally, a thicker carbon shell may reduce the number of Pd active sites exposed within the cavity, significantly decreasing H2 conversion and H2O2 productivity. However, the increased spatial mass transfer constraints due to the thicker carbon shell and more enclosed hollow structure contribute to improved H2O2 selectivity. Hence, H2O2 selectivity increases with the amount of DA. The catalytic performance evaluation results of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts also show that the catalyst exhibits optimal performance when the dosage of DA is 0.35 g. Further, long-term catalytic performance evaluation experiments for 3 h, and hydrogenation and decomposition evaluation experiments of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst were carried out with the results presented in Figs. 5 and 6 , respectively. Fig. 5 shows that the concentration of H2O2 in the solution continuously increases with reaction time, indicating that the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst demonstrates good catalytic activity throughout the reaction. Initially (0.5 h), the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst exhibits high catalytic activity, with the H2O2 concentration rapidly rising to 0.27 % (wt). At the beginning of the reaction, the concentrations of H2, O2 and H2O2 within the micro-reactor cavities of the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst are low. Driven by concentration gradients, H2 and O2 molecules diffuse quickly into the micro-reactor cavity and react with Pd nanoparticles embedded in the porous carbon shell to produce H2O2. Furthermore, the appropriately thick carbon shell suppresses the aggregation of Pd nanoparticles on the carbon shell's inner surface. The average Pd nanoparticle size in the prepared PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst is approximately 6.5 nm (Fig. 2(h)), with a concentration in the 4.5–8.0 nm range. Smaller particle size and narrower size distribution enhance catalytic activity. XPS analysis of the Pd3d spectrum shows a Pd0/Pd2+ ratio of 1.27 (Table S2), endowing the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst with strong H2 dissociation activation ability and moderate O2 adsorption strength. This suppresses side reactions due to excessive O2 activation, which is crucial for improving H2O2 productivity and selectivity under atmospheric pressure. Notably, the nest-like hollow carbon shell, with its high specific surface area and abundant microporous structure, accelerates the circulation and diffusion of reactants and products within the micro-reactor. This ensures that the generated H2O2 quickly desorbs from the Pd active sites and diffuses into the reaction solution, reducing the occurrence of H2O2 hydrogenation and decomposition side reactions caused by H2O2 concentration buildup within the micro-reactor. However, as the reaction progresses, the rate of increase in H2O2 concentration, H2O2 selectivity, and H2 conversion rate diminishes. This may be due to increased H2O2 concentrations in the micro-reactor and reaction solution, which hinder the reaction's forward progression. Additionally, some Pd0 may be oxidized to Pd2+, reducing H2 conversion and H2O2 productivity [44,52],. An appropriate number of Pd active sites, Pd0/Pd2+ ratio, and nitrogen doping in the carbon shell contribute to the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst's ability to withstand harsh reaction conditions. Importantly, the excellent mass transfer and diffusion properties of the nest-like hollow carbon shell effectively suppress the OO bond cleavage side reactions on the Pd surface. Consequently, after 0.5 h of reaction, the decrease in catalytic performance of the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst slows down. ICP-OES measurements show that the Pd loading of the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst before and after the reaction is 4.73 % and 4.69 %, respectively, indicating that the hollow carbon shell structure effectively stabilizes the Pd nanoparticles and prevents their loss or dissolution under harsh reaction conditions. Fig. 6 shows that the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst experiences both hydrogenation and decomposition side reactions of H2O2, with the hydrogenation side reaction being more pronounced than the decomposition reaction, consistent with previously reported studies on Pd catalysts [68–70]. Notably, after 3 h of reaction, the concentration of H2O2 in the solution remains above 90 % (with hydrogenation and decomposition reaction rates of 2738 and 2167 mmol-H2O2/gPd·h-1, respectively). This indicates that the nest-like hollow carbon shell, with its high specific surface area and abundant microporous structure, enhances the circulation and diffusion of H2 and H2O2 within the micro-reactor, effectively preventing severe hydrogenation and decomposition side reactions. Tables 2 and 3 provide a detailed comparison of the structural morphology parameters and catalytic performance evaluation results of DSHP between the nest-shaped hollow-encapsulated PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst and hollow-encapsulated PdMulti@HCS catalyst. The specific surface area, micropore volume, and hollow cavity diameter of both PdMulti@ONHCS and PdMulti@HCS catalyst show minimal differences, and the Pd loading is nearly the same. However, the H2 conversion and H2O2 productivity of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst are 46.4 % and 59.4 % higher, respectively, compared to the PdMulti@HCS catalyst, while the H2O2 selectivity decreases by only 2.2 %. This indicates that structural morphology also is a significant factor influencing the catalytic performance of Pd catalyst for DSHP. Compared to the intact hollow structure of PdMulti@HCS catalyst, the particular nest-shaped opening design of the hollow carbon shell in the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst, combined with the high specific surface area and abundant microporous channels, further enhances mass transfer and diffusion rate, thereby improving H2O2 productivity and H2O2 selectivity. To gain a deeper understanding of the structure-performance relationship between the structural morphology of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst and the catalytic performance in DSHP, molecular dynamics simulation was employed to study the influence of hollow carbon shell on the mass transfer and diffusion of H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH molecules during DSHP. As can be seen from Fig. 3, average pore diameter of carbon nanopores in the hollow carbon shell of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst is mainly 1.5 nm. Therefore, building upon the preliminary experimental results, the PD-15 model (carbon pore diameter of 15 Å, reaction temperature of 273.15 K, with initial concentration of 10 % for reactants in the external region of the reaction system and 5 % for products in the external region of the product system, detailed model parameters and modeling information can be found in the supplementary material.) was firstly chosen as the representative model for molecular dynamics simulation of the reactant system (H2, O2 and CH3OH) and the product system (H2O2 and CH3OH). Fig. 7 (a) depicts the total mean square displacement (MSD) curves for each component of reactant system (H2, O2 and CH3OH) in the PD-15 model. As shown in Fig. 7(a), the total MSD curves of H2 and O2 exhibit small difference, while the total MSD curve of CH3OH is significantly lower than that of H2 and O2. This indicates that H2 and O2 have higher diffusion rate compared to CH3OH, which may be attributed to the molecular dynamics diameter and structure of H2, O2 and CH3OH. The molecular dynamics diameter of H2 and O2 are 2.9 Å and 3.5 Å, respectively, both smaller than 3.8 Å of CH3OH, and the linear structure of H2 and O2 is more conducive to diffusion. Calculated using Einstein equation, the total diffusion coefficients for H2, O2 and CH3OH are 4.461 × 10–10 m2/s, 3.868 × 10–10 m2/s and 1.712 × 10–10 m2/s, respectively. Notably, the total diffusion coefficient of H2 is 2.6 times that of CH3OH, and the total diffusion coefficient of O2 is 2.3 times that of CH3OH. Fig. 7(b) depicts the total MSD curves for each component of the product system (H2O2 and CH3OH). As shown in Fig. 7(b), the total MSD curve of H2O2 is lower than that of CH3OH, indicating that CH3OH has a higher diffusion rate. The total diffusion coefficients of H2O2 and CH3OH are calculated by Einstein equation to be 1.069 × 10–10 m2/s and 1.749 × 10–10 m2/s, respectively, and the total diffusion coefficient of CH3OH is 1.6 times that of H2O2. As the solvent in DSHP, theoretical analysis results of molecular dynamics simulation suggests that CH3OH exhibits a similar level of total diffusion coefficient, both in the reactant and product systems (1.712 × 10–10 m2/s and 1.749 × 10–10 m2/s). This indicates that in both systems, the mass transfer and diffusion capacity of CH3OH is not affected by changes in the solute. Notably, in the PD-15 model, the diffusion rate of H2, O2, CH3OH and H2O2 show a decreasing trend, with the diffusion rate of CH3OH and H2O2 being significantly lower than those of the other components. This suggests that the 15 Å pore size imposed substantial limitation on the diffusion of H2O2 and CH3OH. Fig. 8 (a-d) depicts the diffusion distribution of H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH, respectively. As shown in Fig. 8 (a-d), throughout the entire simulation period, H2, O2 and H2O2 are primarily distributed in the model's external region and the pore region. Notably, there is a minimal change in the concentration of H2, O2 and H2O2 within the pore region. This indicates that, as the simulation progresses, although the total number of H2, O2 and H2O2 within the nanopore does not significantly change, but the diffusion of H2, O2 and H2O2 from the external region into the lower concentration internal region through the carbon nanopore, resulting in a gradual increasing to the concentration of H2, O2 and H2O2 in the inner region. The catalytic performance evaluation of PdMulti@ONHCS catalysts also showed high H2O2 productivity, H2 conversion rate, and H2O2 selectivity in the early stage of DSHP. This indicated that, in the early stages, H2 and O2 molecules in the reaction solution could continuously diffuse into the microreactor of the catalyst and react with the embedded Pd nanoparticles to produce H2O2 under the driving force of concentration gradients. This observation aligned with the results obtained from molecular dynamics simulation. It is worth noting that the adsorption of H2, O2, and H2O2 on the surface of the carbon support occurred in the concentrated phase region, which increased the local concentration of H2, O2, and H2O2 on the surface of the carbon support and contributed to the increase of the concentration-driven mass transfer and diffusion rate. The research result of the PD-15 model indicates that a pore size of 15 Å significantly inhibits the mass transfer and diffusion of H2O2 and CH3OH within and outside the catalyst. For this purpose, the mass transfer and diffusion of H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH at pore sizes of 5 Å (PD-5), 15 Å (PD-15), 25 Å (PD-25), and 50 Å (PD-50) were investigated. Fig. 9 (a-d) presents the total MSD curves for H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH in the reaction system under different pore sizes. As shown in the figure, the total MSD curves for H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH become progressively steeper with increasing pore size, indicating that the total diffusion rate of H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH increase with the pore size. According to the Einstein relation, the total diffusion coefficients for H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH were calculated and are listed in Table 4 . The Table 4 reveals that when the pore size is 5 Å, the total diffusion coefficients for H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH are 2.746 × 10–10 m2/s, 2.376 × 10–10 m2/s, 8.700 × 10–11 m2/s, and 1.615 × 10–10 m2/s, respectively. When the pore size increases to 50 Å, the total diffusion coefficients for H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH increase to 1.104 × 10–9 m2/s, 8.083 × 10–10 m2/s, 3.376 × 10–10 m2/s, and 3.846 × 10–10 m2/s, respectively. This demonstrates that as the pore size continues to increase, the mass transfer resistance within the pores decreases, enhancing the diffusion rates of the components from the concentrated phase to the dilute phase. Hence, the total mass transfer coefficients of all components increase with the pore size. To quantitatively evaluate the impact of pore size on the mass transfer and diffusion of various components, the trajectories of H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH molecules initially located within the pore at time zero (0 ns) were tracked. Using the Einstein relation, the diffusion coefficients of H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH within the pore were calculated, and the results are presented in Table 5 . As shown in the table, the diffusion coefficients of H2 in carbon nanopores with diameters of 5 Å, 15 Å, 25 Å, and 50 Å are 1.200 × 10–10 m2/s, 1.604 × 10–9 m2/s, 1.864 × 10–9 m2/s, and 1.846 × 10–9 m2/s, respectively. When the pore size increases from 5 Å to 15 Å, the diffusion coefficient of H2 increases by 12.4 times, while increasing the pore size from 15 Å to 25 Å results in only a 0.16 times increase in the diffusion coefficient of H2. Furthermore, increasing the pore size to 50 Å does not further increase the diffusion coefficient of H2, indicating that continuing to increase the pore size beyond 25 Å does not effectively enhance the diffusion rate of H2 within the nanopore. Similarly, for O2, the diffusion coefficient increases by a factor of 4.5 when the pore diameter increases from 5 Å to 15 Å, and by 2.1 times when the diameter increases from 15 Å to 25 Å. Further increasing the pore diameter to 50 Å does not result in additional enhancement of the O2 diffusion coefficient. This indicates that when the pore diameter exceeds 25 Å, further enlargement does not significantly improve the diffusion rate of O2 within the pores. Analysis of the diffusion coefficient of H2O2 within the pores reveals that when the pore size increases from 5 Å to 15 Å, the diffusion coefficient of H2O2 increases by 3.2 times, and when the pore size increases from 15 Å to 25 Å, the diffusion coefficient increases by 8.5 times. Further increasing the pore size to 50 Å, the diffusion coefficient of H2O2 increases by an additional 0.3 times, indicating that larger pore size is more favorable for the mass transfer and diffusion of H2O2. Similar to H2O2, the diffusion coefficient of CH3OH within the pores also increases with the enlargement of pore diameter. When the pore size increases from 5 Å to 15 Å, the diffusion coefficient of CH3OH increases by 0.5 times, and when the pore size increases from 15 Å to 25 Å, the diffusion coefficient of CH3OH increases by 2.0 times. Further increasing the pore size to 50 Å, the diffusion coefficient of CH3OH changes very little. Although the diffusion coefficients of H2, O2, H2O2 and CH3OH within the pores increase with the enlargement of pore diameter, further increasing the diameter beyond 25 Å does not significantly enhance their diffusion coefficients. This suggests a marginal effect on the diffusion coefficient of various components within the nanopore. Additionally, it should be noted that smaller pore diameter significantly inhibit the diffusion of H2O2 and CH3OH, making cross-regional mass transfer nearly impossible for these molecules. This phenomenon may be attributed to the polarity and structure of H2O2 and CH3OH molecules. Therefore, when designing the pore structure of the catalyst's hollow carbon shell, it is crucial to increase the pore diameter sufficiently to facilitate the diffusion of H2O2 and CH3OH, while ensuring adequate mass transfer of reactants H2 and O2. This approach aims to achieve superior catalytic performance for DSHP. In conclusion, both experimental investigation and molecular dynamics simulation have indicated that the spatial mass transfer and diffusion resistance in hollow-structured Pd catalyst for DSHP primarily resides within the carbon nanopore of hollow carbon shell, and the constraint effect of spatial mass transfer is significant. This is because the H2 and O2 molecules, as reactants, must first undergo mass transfer and diffusion through the carbon nanopore of hollow carbon shell before reaching the Pd active surface for the reaction to generate H2O2. The hollow-encapsulated PdMulti@HCS catalyst features a intact hollow cavity with the carbon shell primarily consisting of microporous structure which will significantly intensifies the constraint effect of spatial mass transfer for the reactant H2 and O2 molecules. Meanwhile, the mass transfer and diffusion capacity of O2 within the carbon nanopore is weaker than that of H2, resulting in a higher H2 coverage and lower O2 coverage on the Pd active surface inside the hollow cavity. As a result, this would lead to a significant reduction in both H2 conversion rate and H2O2 formation rate. Simultaneously, the generated H2O2 may also experience delayed detachment from the Pd active surface due to the substantial mass transfer and diffusion resistance posed by the carbon shell. Consequently, H2O2 cannot efficiently diffuse through the carbon nanopore from the hollow cavity into the reaction solution, resulting in an elevated H2O2 concentration within the cavity. This heightened concentration exacerbates the extent of hydrogenation and decomposition side reactions, further reducing H2O2 productivity. However, it is precisely because of the strong constraint effect of spatial mass transfer that the coverage rate of H2 and O2 on the Pd active surface is reduced as a whole. This significantly inhibits the extent of the undesired side reactions which H2 and O2 directly react on the Pd active surface to form H2O, and the selectivity of H2O2 is improved to a certain extent. Then the distinctive nest-shape opening design of the hollow carbon shell in PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst effectively enlarges the pore size locally, reducing the constraint effect of spatial mass transfer on the catalyst. This enhancement not only promoted the adsorption of reactant H2 and O2 molecules onto the Pd active sites for H2O2 generation but also facilitated the prompt detachment of generated H2O2 from Pd active sites, allowing rapid diffusion into the reaction solution. Consequently, it efficiently suppressed the dissociation of OO species on the Pd active surface, which could lead to serious hydrogenation and decomposition side reactions and significantly improve both H2 conversion and H2O2 productivity. However, it is noteworthy that due to the unique characteristic of H2 and O2 directly forming H2O on Pd active surface, the appropriately designed nest-shape opening in the hollow carbon shell of the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst, while enhancing the mass transfer and diffusion rate of reactant H2 and O2 molecules and product H2O2 molecules, increase both H2 conversion and H2O2 productivity. Nonetheless, the accelerated mass transfer and diffusion ability also results in a more open catalyst structure, weakening the spatial mass transfer constraint. This, in turn, facilitates the easy adsorption of H2 and O2 molecules on the high-energy active sites of small-sized Pd nanoparticles, directly generating H2O, thereby compromising the H2O2 selectivity to some extent compared with PdMulti@HCS catalyst with a intact hollow structure. In a word, the structural morphology of Pd catalyst significantly influences the catalytic performance of DSHP. This impact is not only on the number and distribution of Pd active sites but more importantly on the spatial mass transfer and diffusion of reactant and product molecules as well as on the reaction kinetics pathways, thereby affecting the catalytic performance of Pd catalyst in DSHP. 4 Conclusion In this study, a novel approach was proposed by successfully constructing a nest-shaped hollow-encapsulated Pd catalyst named PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst using hard template sacrifice method and high-temperature explosion effect, and experiment and molecular dynamics simulation were employed to investigate the structure-performance relationship of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst for DSHP at atmospheric pressure. Both experiment results and molecular dynamics simulation results show that the mass transfer resistance in the PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst for DSHP mainly exists in the hollow carbon shell pores, which are predominantly microporous. This leads to a strong constraint effect of spatial mass transfer. However, the distinctive nest-shape opening design of the hollow carbon shell effectively mitigates this constraint, reducing spatial mass transfer resistance. This enhancement in the mass transfer rate of reactant and product molecules within the microreactor cavity results in improved H2O2 productivity and H2O2 selectivity. The study results also demonstrate that in the design and construction of hollow-structured Pd catalyst, precise control of the pore structure of the porous shell layer is particularly necessary to reduce spatial mass transfer and diffusion resistance and shorten the mass transfer and diffusion process of reactants and products, and controlling the size, number, and distribution position of Pd active metal which enables hollow-structured Pd catalyst to exhibit excellent catalytic performance in DSHP. coredata.dc:description: A well-defined structural morphology can significantly construct a special catalytic micro-reaction environment to enhance the catalytic performance of Pd catalyst in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen (DSHP). In this study, SiO2 was used as a rigid template, PdCl2 as the Pd precursor, and dopamine hydrochloride (DA) as the carbon and nitrogen source to synthesize a nest-shaped hollow-encapsulated Pd catalyst named PdMulti@ONHCS. This catalyst was successfully constructed via high-temperature pyrolysis of poly dimethyl diallyl ammonium chloride (PDDA), which generated a blasting effect crucial for this formation. Characterization analysis, catalytic performance evaluation experiment, and molecular dynamics simulation were conducted to explore the structure-performance relationship of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst in DSHP. Both experimental and simulation results consistently showed that the nest-shaped hollow structure of PdMulti@ONHCS catalyst created a distinctive catalytic microreactor environment with a spatial mass transfer constraint, which was not only conducive to adsorption and enrichment of H2 and O2 at Pd active sites to produce H2O2. In addition, the generated H2O2 can be desorbed from Pd active sites in time and rapidly diffused into the reaction solution, effectively inhibiting the dissociation of species containing OO bonds on the Pd surface, resulting in severe hydrogenation and decomposition side reactions, and improving H2O2 productivity and selectivity.
